titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Weather cold— Mr: Murray dined with us— Mrs: A. went with Madame O’Farril to the play.— Latter part of the Evening at Doctor Brown’s— Received a letter from Mr: King.

2.— Evening and supper at Baron d’Engeström’s— Played whist with him, the Count de la Gardie, and Madam de Heinitz.— Steibelt and his wife were there; but we had not much music.— The party was small. About 60 persons.

3. The king and queen came to town Yesterday— Paid a visit this afternoon to Madame de Voss, found at her apartments a great crowd of visitors— Evening at the Minister Arnim’s— Company very large. Play’d Whist with Mr: Knoblauch.

4. Mrs: Adams went with Mrs: O’Farril and paid all the usual visits at the several Courts— They afterwards came to Count Schulenburg’s where there was a very large party to spend the Evening and sup, on occasion of his daughter’s marriage two days ago, to Count Hatzfeldt— Mrs: O’Farril in turning round in a room, fell down upon the carpet, and broke her leg, just above the ancle— Mrs: A. was so shock’d at the sight of her sufferings, and overstrained in exertions to assist her that she soon after fainted away— With the help of two men I brought her home and from eight o’clock in the Evening untill midnight, she had a continual succession of fainting fits, and cramps almost amounting to convulsions— Madame de Sartoris and Miss Bischoffwerder came home with us, and gave her all the assistance in their power.— She slept a little in the night— I did not close my eyes.

5. Mrs: A continued all the forepart of the day excessively weak, and fainted again several times.— Madame de Sartoris and Miss Bischoffwerder called to see her— Count Brühl, Mr: Arbuthnot and Mr: Murray, likewise called in the forenoon— And Mr: O’Farril in the afternoon— I went to Madame d’Engeström’s and to Count Schulenburg’s, but found neither at home.— Towards evening Mrs: A. was a little better— I was obliged to go for about an hour to the ball at Baron Alvensleben’s, where the king and all the royal family were present.— Mr: Murray went with me and was presented to them— I came home soon after eight o’clock.— Miss Brown spent about an hour with Mrs: A.

6. Mrs: Adams is this day much better—and recovering for the present. Countess Brühl and her daughter Mary called in the afternoon—as did Mrs: Schickler and Bell Brown.— I called at the Spanish Minister’s, but he was just going out— Went to Bellevue, where was a large company— I staid not above an hour. Walk’d before dinner with the Chevalier d’Aguilar.

7. Mr: Murray called in the forenoon to see us.— Mrs: A. continues better— In the Evening I was about an hour at the Vicomte d’Anadia’s ball— The dancing was not to begin untill after supper—I did not stay.— In the morning I took a lesson of German.

8. Mrs: A. still better— Walking before dinner, met Baron Ompteda, and walked with him— Mr: Murray dined with us.— Evening at the Queen’s court— The king being unwell did not make his appearance.— I stayed only untill the Queen sat down to cards, and Mr: Murray was presented to the princesses— Upon coming home found Miss Brown, with Mrs: A— Read to her the part of the first book of Oberon, which I have done.

9. Mr: Murray called upon me this forenoon.— Letters from Mr: Murray at the Hague and from my brother. Mr: Arbuthnot spent the first part of the evening with us— Sophie Neale called to see Mrs: Adams.— Read the third and fourth books of Pope’s Iliad.
10. Wrote to Mr: Murray— Mrs: Adams went this forenoon and spent a couple of hours with Mrs: O’Farril— Read this evening the 5th: Iliad. Had this morning a lesson of German.

11. Dined at Count Finkenstein’s, with a large diplomatic company. Got there very late— I had mistaken the day, thinking the invitation was for to-morrow, untill after the clock struck two;— Mrs: Adams spent the Evening with Mrs: O’Farril— Read part of Shakspear’s poem of Venus and Adonis.
12. Lesson of German— It is now merely reduced to an examination of my daily translations from Oberon. Evening at Baron Alvensleben’s ball. Play’d Whist.— Mrs: Adams at Mrs: O’Farril’s.

13. Countess Brühl and her daughters, Miss Emily Zennert, Mr: and Madame de Sartoris, and the Miss Brown’s, all here at tea— Mr: Arbuthnot and Mr: Murray came in afterwards.— Wrote a letter to my brother— Made this morning the extract from the 11th: book of Oberon.

14. Letter to Mr: Murray (Hague)— Lesson of German this morning— Mr: Murray dined with us. He goes early to-morrow morning, for Vienna; through Dresden— Mrs: Adams spent the Evening with Mrs O’Farril— Read the remnant of Shakspeares Venus and Adonis, and began his Tarquin & Lucrece.

15. Weather very cold indeed, but very fine— Mrs: Adams spent the Evening again with Mrs: O’Farril— Finished this day the analytical extract from Oberon, and likewise the translation of the first book; and began the second— The abbé Denina called upon me— And Mr: Arbuthnot spent a couple of hours with me— Read him the last stanza’s of my translation— Reaumur, 9. degrees below 0.

16.— Weather continues extremely cold— Mrs: Adams was seized this afternoon, about an hour after dinner, more suddenly than I have ever known before, with extreme illness— It continued with great violence, untill 10 o’clock at night— Sent an excuse to Bellevue.

17. Mrs: Adams had a bad night, and continued extremely weak all the fore part of this day. I walked however before dinner— Towards evening she grew somewhat better.— Spent the whole of it with her.— Was obliged to neglect my letter writing for this day.

18. Mrs: A— appears again to be slowly recovering— Snow— Walked through the fair, opposite the palace; and afterwards in the wood.— Bell Brown called and pass’d the Evening with Mrs: A. I was at the Minister Heinitz’s, where was a large company to supper.— Play’d whist with Miss Hagen, Madame Lichrowsky and MadameI came home before supper.

19. The weather again cold— Called this afternoon at the Spanish Minister’s Found Mrs: O’Farril as well as possible in her situation and in good Spirits— Evening at the Minister Alvensleben’s ball— Played whist with Madame de Magalon (a daughter of the Marquis d’Argens[)], the Minister Schroetter, and Mr: Knoblauch.— Home soon after nine—

20. The thermometer this morning at 11 degrees below 0. (Reaumur’s.)— Mrs: Adams continues yet unwell— Wrote a letter to Mr: Murray.— Read the Comte de Tressan’s Huon de Bordeaux—from which Wieland has borrowed almost the whole of his first book— I spend now perhaps too much time upon my translation from the Oberon.

21. Mrs: Adams is better— The weather continues very cold. Walking under the trees, met the Chevalier d’Aguilar, who is too much of a philosopher for me.— Read this Evening, the first Canto of Spenser’s Faëry Queene; and the sixth book of Pope’s Iliad.

22. Weather again very cold— My translations this day went on with unusual facility.— Was at Court, this Evening. It was somewhat crowded— The king was present.— I staid only untill the Queen had seated herself at the card table.

23. Dined at the Swedish Minister’s—with a very large, and chiefly diplomatic company. Madame d’Engeström the only Lady at table— After dinner the Baron told me he had a proposition to make about keeping jointly some frigates in the Mediterranean, between Sweden, Denmark and U.S.— He will write me about it— Bell Brown spent the Evening with Mrs: Adams— Read to them the second and third Canto’s of the Faëry Queene, book 1:

24. Walk’d to the fair, before dinner.— Snow’d somewhat— Took my lesson of German in the afternoon from four to five o’clock, instead of the morning— Read this Evening the 4th: and 5th: books of the Red Cross Knight’s legend, in the Faëry Queene— The description of pride’s six councillors in the fourth book, is indeed very beautiful.
25. Christmas day— Snowy. Call’d in the Evening at Doctor Brown’s— Count Brühl, and his family there. Played a game of chess with him. Home early and read a Canto of the Faëry Queene.

26. This day was the fourth and last of Baron Alvensleben’s balls— I met there, my old acquaintance, the Commandeur d’Araujo, who proposes to spend the winter here.— The Marquis de Gallo was likewise there. Played Chess with M. d’Aguilar.— The two eldest Miss Browns spent the Evening with Mrs: A.

27. Dined at the Danish Minister, Baron Rosenkrantz’s; a company of about twenty persons. M: d’Araujo told me that he had seen Mr: Wieland at Weymar; who shewed him the English translation of his Oberon, by Mr: Southby; with which he is much pleased— M. d’Araujo, does not like the Oberon.— Called at the Spanish Ministers to see Madam O’Farril, who is recovering fast from her unfortunate accident— Evening at the Minister Heinitz’s.— Play’d Whist with Count Moltke— M: d’Engeström, and Madame de

28. The weather has again become extremely cold— Reaumur’s thermometer this evening at 15. below 0. Mr: Sartoris called upon me this morning to desire I would send round cards with a friend of his. Mr: Engeström likewise called and left a note, to be transmitted to America; concerning a plan to keep frigates cruising, in the Mediterranean, in concert between Sweden, Denmark & U.S.— Read this evening a Canto of the Faery Queene— Finished the second, and began the third book of Oberon.

29. Reaumur’s thermometer stood this morning at 18 degrees below 0.— The whole day was excessively cold and uncomfortable— Mrs: A. was unwell with a head-ache, and in the Evening very ill— The queen’s Court was put off, on account of the very bad weather—

30— The cold has somewhat moderated, but continues this day chiefly from 10 to 12 degrees below 0— Walked in the park— In the Evening read a Canto of the Fairy Queen; and the 7th: book of Pope’s Iliad— Spenser’s description of Despair, is like all his allegorical personages, fanciful and expressive.
31 Mrs: Adams unwell— Doctor Brown here this forenoon— Evening at the Chanoine Rochow’s of Rekahn. Played Whist with Countess Moltke—Madame de Zastrow, and Mr: Knoblauch.

Day. Rise at different hours from 5 to 8. generally, about 7.— German lesson, or translating Oberon, till 10. Breakfast.— Read or write as I have occasion till 2.— Walk— Dine at 3.— Translate another Stanza, from Oberon— Read Spenser or Pope’s Iliad; or spend the Evening out; untill 10.— Bed at 11.

The year would in general have been a pleasant one, but for the state of my wife’s health which has been almost continually bad, and concerning which I am even now deeply concerned— The subject preys upon my spirits more than I can express.— I have written during the year somewhat more than usual. Principally in the months of May and June, when I made the translation of Bülow’s book.— Since the middle of November too, I have amused myself with translating from Wieland’s Oberon— A work which serves in some degree to withdraw my reflections from painful subjects which have too great a tendency to engross them— I have learnt in the course of the year something more of the German language, which I can read with tolerably facility— And I have sufficiently ascertained that I never shall speak it—
